awd_titl_txt: POSE: Phase I:  Towards a WebAssembly Research Ecosystem
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is funded by Pathways to Enable Open-Source Ecosystems (POSE) which seeks to harness the power of open-source development for the creation of new technology solutions to problems of national and societal importance.  WebAssembly (Wasm for short), is a new, portable compilation target for the Web that has sparked a revolution in how web applications are built. Since its appearance in major browsers in 2017, Wasm has brought a new, powerful capability to the Web platform and begun expanding rapidly in Edge computing, Internet of Things (IoT) contexts, and embedded systems. Despite this momentum, the Wasm research community lacks shared infrastructure. This project identifies key missing pieces of research infrastructure related tools and artifacts, such as good benchmarks, that need an open source ecosystem to flourish. The project’s impacts are an open source ecosystem centered around Wasm research with broader impacts of accelerating Wasm development and standardization and increasing the platform's usefulness to researchers. The project’s novelties lie in the planning and development of a Wasm Research Center, including determining of the governance structure, developing partnerships and funding agreements, establishing a collaborative model for groups of researchers, and scoping the infrastructure and tools that the ecosystem maintains.

Key to the success of this effort to establish a WebAssembly open-source ecosystem is outreach to researchers and industry partners to determine the scope and capabilities of needed tools and benchmarks to advance the state of Wasm research. An important aspect of this outreach is regular contact with the Wasm Worldwide Web Consortium Community Group (CG), a functioning industrial standards body that has successfully developed the standard and test suite. This project supplements the CG with an additional set of ecosystems supporting research around Wasm.  Specific broader impacts of this work include: improving the security and performance of applications, advancing software assurance through mechanized proofs, supporting a solid Edge Computing landscape, advancing the Web platform through additional features, increasing the range and diversity of supported languages, and filling the pipeline of talent and expertise in virtual machines.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This NSF project focused on establishing and nurturing an open source ecosystem around WebAssembly Research by supporting the activities of the PI and co-PI in scoping/discovering a hybrid research/development ecosystem that collaborates with the standards body governing Wasm and thus contributes to long-term objectives. This grant helped nurture collaboration amongst researchers, design and establish governance over organizations and researchers who build Wasm tools, and provide for sustainability of the ecosystem through industrial partnerships. Amongst its primary outcomes was, as outlined in the proposal, the successful establishment of a WebAssembly Research Center at Carnegie Mellon University directed by the PIs.

 

Background.

 

WebAssembly (Wasm) is a modern, portable compilation target first introduced in major browsers in 2017 to bring higher performance and efficiency to the Web by enabling languages like C, C++, and Rust to run at near-native speeds. This capability has extended the Web's potential, allowing developers to create applications that were previously impractical due to the limitations of JavaScript. The impact of Wasm has rapidly expanded beyond the Web. In Edge computing, it provides a lightweight, efficient sandboxed execution environment suitable for distributed systems at scale. In IoT, it offers a versatile, secure runtime capable of handling the constraints of devices with limited resources. Wasm has even made inroads into embedded and cyber-physical systems, powering applications on platforms as resource-constrained as Arduino microcontrollers. Offering portability, security, and efficiency as well as a robust, open specification, it’s being targeting now by over 40 mainstream programming languages.

Open Standard and Development Process.

WebAssembly (Wasm) was designed through an open, collaborative process from its inception, setting it apart from most previously developed code formats. Governed by the Worldwide Web Consortium (W3C), the Wasm standard is developed transparently, with its text, working materials, and proposals hosted on GitHub. The W3C WebAssembly Community Group (CG) ensures broad engagement in the standardization process. Wasm’s ecosystem thrives on open source contributions  like the WebAssembly test suite, LLVM Wasm backend, WABT, Emscripten, and wasi-sdk are freely available, alongside optimization tools like Binaryen. Many research tools exist as well. Our team, with partial support from NSF RINGS Grant #2148301, is developing Wizard, a research-oriented Wasm engine designed to push the boundaries of Wasm’s capabilities and foster further innovation. This grant helped support organizing collaboration amongst researchers that develop tools like Wizard.

Building and Nurturing a Collaborative CG/Research Ecosystem.

This grant identified a key missing piece in the ecosystem: collaboration amongst researchers and organization and governance for open-source tools. It proposed to establish a research center and regular modes of collaboration, including increasing collaboration amongst researchers and synergy with the standards body. To that end, as part of participation in the standards process, PI Titzer organized regular Research Day events that were co-located with in-person CG meetings in October 2022 (hosted at Google in San Francisco), October 2023 (hosted at Google in Munich), and June 2024 (hosted at CMU in Pittsburgh). Each Research Day consisted of a workshop-like organization, with talks by both invited academic researchers and CG members, as well as poster presentations. These events increased collaboration amongst researchers who may or may not already be involved in proposals and were widely popular with CG participants. Also, as part of the establishment of the WRC, we hosted a monthly research discussion series.

Establishment of the WebAssembly Research Center at Carnegie Mellon University.

A key goal and outcome of this project was establishing the WebAssembly Research Center at Carnegie Mellon University. Partner agreements, governance structure, collaboration plans, and research projects were explored as part of the activities of PIs and co-PIs. Discovering partner needs and priorities was key to finding alignment and starting research projects that benefit the community and specific partner priorities. With the support of this grant, the PIs established the WebAssembly Research Center at CMU in September 2023 with founding members DFinity, Siemens and Shopify, with PI Titzer as director and PI Miller as co-director. In January 2024 the first partners’ meeting was held at CMU, where faculty involved in the center, including nine affiliated CMU faculty and 6 graduate students attended. In April of 2024, the WRC announced expanded membership, including two new partners, Siemens and Woven. Since that time, faculty and students have undertaken research projects that support partners’ goals such as distributed fault-injection, bytecode-based instrumentation, engine-based instrumentation, low-level kernel interfaces for Wasm, trace recording and replay techniques, benchmarking, application of Wasm to cyber-physical systems, and studying dynamic language performance. All of the tools and techniques developed in those partner-supported research projects have been made open source. In particular, a key stated goal and nascent research area addressed through activities in the center was to improve benchmarking, and collaboration with KAIST and the University of Stuttgart produced a new set of benchmarks derived from real-world Wasm web applications, dubbed Wasm-R3.


Last Modified: 12/28/2024
Modified by: Benjamin L Titzer
